The Automated but Risky Game: Modeling Agent-to-Agent Negotiations and Transactions in Consumer Markets

This research paper explores the potential and risks of utilizing AI agents to automate negotiations and transactions within consumer markets. The study investigates a future scenario where both consumers and merchants employ AI agents to handle these processes. The core questions addressed are: 1) How do different Large Language Model (LLM) agents perform when negotiating on behalf of users, and 2) What are the potential risks associated with fully automating negotiations and deal-making using AI agents in consumer settings? The authors designed an experimental framework to evaluate the capabilities and performance of various LLM agents across real-world negotiation and transaction scenarios. Their analysis revealed a significant imbalance in deal-making outcomes, with different AI agents exhibiting substantial variations in their ability to secure favorable deals for their respective users. Critically, the research identified a concerning trend: LLMs can display behavioral anomalies that pose a substantial risk of financial loss for both consumers and merchants when integrated into real-world decision-making processes. The study highlights the need for careful consideration and mitigation strategies when deploying AI agents in sensitive areas like consumer transactions. The research suggests that the interaction between AI agents in consumer markets is inherently unbalanced, creating opportunities for exploitation and potential harm. Further investigation is needed to understand and address the behavioral characteristics of LLMs and their impact on financial outcomes. The paper contributes to the growing body of work on agent-based modeling and the ethical considerations surrounding the use of AI in commercial contexts. The findings underscore the importance of robust oversight and risk management protocols to ensure responsible innovation in this rapidly evolving field. The experimental framework provides a valuable tool for assessing the performance and potential vulnerabilities of AI agents in complex negotiation environments.

AI agents LLM agents negotiations transactions consumer markets deal-making risk behavioral anomaly price retail price
